A thremmatologist, to be precise.
A thremmatologist? Then you're well qualified to tell me about these.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor shows her the Demeter seeds.

Dialogue.Line: Stewardess! Stewardess!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Janet comes over.

Dialogue.Line: Something wrong, Professor?
Fetch the Security officer.
Can I help?
At once!
May I be told what's wrong, Professor?
This man's a thief.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Janet uses her comm. device.

Dialogue.Line: Mister Rudge to the passenger lounge, please.
_Tact. Finesse._ Now what have you landed us in?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: In the doorway to the small lab at the back.

Dialogue.Line: What was that?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Something runs away.

Dialogue.Line: Nothing. Pull yourself together, Bruchner.
There's someone in the hold.
Bruchner, you're allowing hysteria to take
I know what I saw. There was a movement.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Mogarian hides behind some barrels. _Eventually he makes a break for it, and Bruchner and Doland give chase._

Dialogue.Line: That puts an entirely different complexion on the situation. Pity your friend the comedian wasn't as lucid.
I never had a chance to be
I can't understand why they were in cabin six, or why a mineralogist would steal them.
Are they special, Professor?
Yes, just what I was going to
Demeter seeds? Yes, they are. They represent a tremendous advance, a colossal leap.
Do they?
What did you call them? The Demeter seeds?
The name of a god
Food of the gods. Bruchner, my assistant, bit of a romantic, highly strung, he christened them.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Rudge enters and talks with Janet.

Dialogue.Line: That still doesn't explain
He wasn't just being pretentious. They'll increase potential yield threefold. And even more, they'll grow in desert sand.
Er.
What is it, man? Don't stand there hovering.
You sent for him.
I did? Oh, yes. Not to worry.
But I do worry, especially when serious allegations are made. You accused the Doctor of being a thief.
Oh, that. A mistake. The fellow may be a fool, but he's not a criminal.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor huffs, tosses a Demeter seed into the air, catches it in his mouth and eats it.

Dialogue.Line: Project our course through the sector ahead. Put us onto a straighter course. Reduce the diversion to a point naught three safety margin.
I estimate that brings our ETA forward by seventy two hours, sir.
Seventy two hours closer to getting expert investigators on board. Carry on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Two Mogarians are playing Space Invaders on a hologram screen between them. The game finishes and the screen vanishes. Janet brings Mel and the Doctor tea and biscuits.

Dialogue.Line: No, Doctor.
No.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor lets go of the biscuit, and Janet moves on.

Dialogue.Line: No, thank you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The liner judders, and Kimber staggers. Commodore Travers catches him.

Dialogue.Line: No need for concern. Just a navigational adjustment. As you can see, it doesn't even require my presence on the bridge. Now, for your information, the change of course will bring our landfall forward by seventy two hours.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Mogarians chatter at him.

Dialogue.Line: Switch on your translator.
Surely we are approaching the sector with the Black Hole of Tartarus.
That's correct.
If you are saving time, we must be going closer to the black hole.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A third Mogarian joins them.

Dialogue.Line: There's no danger. The safety margin is more than adequate.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The second Mogarian turns on his translator.

Dialogue.Line: That is hardly a denial.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The third Mogarian speaks without his translator on. The Doctor notices.

Dialogue.Line: Simply a bromide.
You sought reassurance, I've given it.
That word reassurance, bears sinister undertones for we Mogarians.
Indeed?
It is the word the Earthlings used when first they persuaded us to allow them to sink mines on Mogar.
A limited concession was all they requested, and now they are stripping our planet bare.
Truth is a stranger to the Earthlings.
If you'll excuse me, politics do not come into my realm of influence.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Doland and Bruchner are talking to Janet.

Dialogue.Line: Then they should.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Travers leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Who are you? Another prospector?
Only of knowledge. I have visited your planet. It's very rich in natural resources.
Which will soon be exhausted if these Earthlings are not restrained. They are going through the universe like a plague of interplanetary locusts.
Are we to be subjected to a dissertation on interplanetary politics now, Sagacity?
Is that all you think it was?
Mining rights, Mogarians versus Earthlings. What else would you call that?
You are so pathetically intent on incriminating me you haven't been watching what's going on!
My eyes never left the screen.
Well, you may have been selected to prosecute me, Valeyard, but I hope you'll never be chosen to defend me.
An occasion that will not arise, Doctor. Your lives are forfeit, as I have ably proven.
Something vital just happened in that scene, and the Valeyard perversely switched our attention to more trivial matters.
Then for pity's sake tell us what it was that happened and enjoy your moment of triumph.
Triumph? There's no cause for celebration. One of the occupants of that lounge is about to die.
Another murder?
Yes. And if you had been watching, you would know who was the intended victim.
Gentlemen, is this case to be resolved with a battle of words or to be conducted via the Matrix?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The three Mogarians are sitting at a table. Janet brings Enzu a drink and he sips it through a straw. Travers and Rudge are on an upper catwalk, watching.

Dialogue.Line: You've drawn a blank where Edwardes is concerned?
Yes, sir. Perhaps we should search the passenger cabins.
No. The passengers are already uneasy. Do you want them to realise they're trapped with a killer on the loose?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Professor Lasky gets up and goes to whisper with Bruchner and Doland.

Dialogue.Line: You're very quiet, Mel. Not quite your style to go into a brown study.
Brown study? Is the vocabulary of all the Time Lords so antediluvian?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Enzu gets up, choking then collapses. The Doctor rushes over and tries to remove his face plate. Travers stops him.

Dialogue.Line: Are you trying to kill him?
I'm trying to save him!
He will die if you remove his helmet.
Mogarians can't breathe oxygen. Surely you're aware of that?
He's not a Mogarian!
He's not?
Then who is he?
If you'll kindly allow me to remove his face plate? I fear this poor fellow is beyond help.
It's Grenville!
Grenville?
The passenger from cabin six.
The man who's supposed to have been dumped in the pulveriser.
His name isn't Grenville. It's Hallett.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Travers checks for a pulse then uses his comm.

Dialogue.Line: Send a stretcher party to the lounge.
Yes, sir. I'll organise that immediately.
Carry on, Mister Rudge.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Travers leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Poor Mister Hallett. I knew it was Hallett. I recognised him, remember?
You recognised him?
Yes.
But he denied it. He insisted his name was Grenville.
Well, he would.
Well, whether his name's Grenville or Hallett, why did he stage his own death in the pulveriser?
This gentleman's just given us the answer.
I have?
Hallett had presumably been assigned to investigate something or somebody on this ship. Then he had the bad fortune to be recognised. A chance encounter that put his entire mission in jeopardy.
Are you saying we had an undercover agent aboard and I wasn't informed?
Well, you may have been a suspect.
Me?
Together with everyone else on this voyage.
Is all this guesswork, or have you any more tricks up your sleeve?
No tricks, Mister Rudge. I knew Hallett, and admired him. But I assure you, until I removed that face plate I had no idea he was on board.
All nice and lily white, Doctor, but it does leave one nasty little problem.
It does?
How did you know the dead man wasn't a Mogarian?
Yes, how did you know? Have you been editing the Matrix and denying the court all the evidence to which it is entitled?
That would be a serious offence, Doctor.
At the risk of appearing impertinent, Sagacity, I would point out that you, the Valeyard, and everyone here present could have acquired the same knowledge.
Perhaps we may hear your explanation.
With respect, you will not hear it from me.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor turns on the Matrix screen. It has gone back to the point where the Mogarians first approach Travers about the course correction.

Dialogue.Line: Switch on your translator. ATZA [on screen]: Surely we are approaching the sector with the Black Hole of Tartarus.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor winds forward.

Dialogue.Line: There's no danger. The safety margin is more than adequate.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The second Mogarian turns on his translator.

Dialogue.Line: That is hardly a denial. ENZU [on screen]: Simply a bromide.
As you saw, the bogus Mogarian did not switch on his translator.

Very astute of you, Doctor, but don't stop there. Let us assume the murdered man was responsible for the mayday call. Perhaps you'll now direct your deductive gifts towards justifying his extraordinary behaviour.
Yes, the investigator Hallett's methods were very unorthodox.
Agreed, and I am indebted to the prosecutor for putting his finger on the nub of my defence, the reason why I could no longer stay on the sidelines.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and Mel are looking down from the catwalk.

Dialogue.Line: Anyone there could have poisoned his drink.
Providing us with a plethora of suspects.
Us? Do I detect a commitment at last? Because of Hallett's death? You said you admired him.
I did. He was one of a rare breed. A maverick. Even the highly organised society of the 30th century has need of his kind. He'll be missed. And he left these seeds for me to find.
To lead you to where I've been telling you all along. The Hydroponic Centre.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The guard on duty at the Isolation room goes to investigate a rattling grill.

Dialogue.Line: What are you doing away from your post? The Isolation room is under no circumstances to be left unguarded. If it happens again, I shall report you to the Commodore.
Hallett must have sent that mayday call.
Yes, he wanted me here as a catalyst, and to divert attention away from his own activities.
You'd do that without being asked.
Hallett was an unorthodox man, but he was also a subtle man. So why did he resort to such blunderbuss tactics? Why use me as a Judas goat?
Well, he was running out of time. The mayday message said as much. Perative traitor be identified before landing Earth. I'd guess the incomplete word was imperative, wouldn't you?
Do you know, I've always envied you that.
I shall probably regret this, but go on, I'll buy it. Envied me what?
Your amazing ability for almost total recall.
Compliments. You are undergoing a change.
I could have been comparing you to an elephant. Well, figuratively speaking. They never forget.
Doctor, I realise you're trying to take my mind off poor Edwardes.
If you'd rather wait here
No.
What have you got there?
A leaf from Hallett's pocket.
I didn't see you take it.
Ah ha! Neither did anyone else. Another one of my tricks.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He makes the leaf disappear from one hand and reappear in the other.

Dialogue.Line: What do you make of these pods, Mel?
I'm not into agronomy. Ask the professor.
Ah. Thremmatology. The professor said she was a thremmatologist.
You're going to have to enlighten me. It's out of my range.
The science of breeding or propagating animals and plants under domestication.
I'm not much wiser.
Well, think, Mel. You've got a good brain. Think.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor steps inside an empty pod.

Dialogue.Line: I wonder what came out of this?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Probably the thing with green-tinged vision making its way through the service tunnels of the liner.

Dialogue.Line: Will you end this charade, this pathetic pretence at normality. Can't you accept we're on the brink of disaster?
Bruchner, will you stop panicking? Our work must remain secret whatever the cost.
You're completely without conscience, Doland, I'm aware of that, but I expected the professor to grasp the enormity of our folly.
So you're suggesting that we jeopardise years of scientific research for the sake of some hypothetical danger?
Exactly. We've no reason to believe the results of our experiments are other than benign.
Benign? Have you been in the Isolation Room lately?
An unfortunate mishap that has no relevance to this situation. In any case, it's academic now.
I lack your lofty detachment.

Do you also lack loyalty, Bruchner, to your colleagues. Before we left Mogar, we agreed that our discovery should be divulged to no one, no one, until we reached Earth. Unless you have concrete evidence to prove there is danger, I expect you to keep your word.
You simply don't understand, do you. The crime we are committing in the name of science will make us infamous!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Something is watching them through a grill.

Dialogue.Line: That's assuming there's anyone left to pass judgement.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Just down from the Isolation room.

Dialogue.Line: Decided to get some rest, Mister Kimber?
Yes, though I doubt if I'll sleep. At my age, one doesn't like to be reminded of mortality.
May I fetch you a warm drink? It might help.
Thank you. That's very gracious.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Janet leaves. Inside his cabin, something watches him undress from the bathroom. Kimber slides the door back and gets a thorn stuck into his neck by a hand made up of leaves. He collapses. Janet returns with the hot drink and knocks on the door.

Dialogue.Line: It's the stewardess, sir.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Janet knocks on the bathroom door.

Dialogue.Line: I've brought your warm drink, sir. Shall I leave it on the dressing table?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The leafy hand turns on the shower. Janet leaves.
The Doctor and Mel pass Janet, and see Lasky leaving the Isolation room.

Dialogue.Line: What's a thremmatologist doing in an isolation room wearing a surgical mask?
Seeing as there's only one way to find out, you've got two problems.
Two?
Apart from getting rid of the guard, you're going to need a mask, and you can hardly ask the professor to lend you hers.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Something rattles in the bulkheads. The Doctor takes an axe and sets off the fire alarm.

Dialogue.Line: Did you hear that?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The guard rushes up.

Dialogue.Line: Quickly, the lounge! There are passengers trapped! On the double, man! There are lives at stake.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The guard takes the axe and runs off.
The Doctor and Mel take smoke masks from the fire point and enter -

Dialogue.Line: No. Stop her. Stop Lasky.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ruth starts to sit up and we see that she has a large leaf growing up behind her head.

Dialogue.Line: Got to stop her, stop her. Stop Lasky.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Lasky enters with Doland and Bruchner.

Dialogue.Line: Out! Out!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The men hustle the Doctor and Mel out while Lasky puts a gas mask with a small canister over Ruth's face.

Dialogue.Line: What's going on in there? What are you trying to hide? Will you please stop mauling me?
I should drop the innocent party act if I were you. Any moment now, that guard will be back. He's going to be even less enchanted by your antics.
Never mind the guard. That monstrosity, what is it in there?
Does the Commodore know what's being isolated in there?

I don't know by whose authority you ask, but if it'll put a stop you your meddling, I'll explain. That monstrosity, as you call her, is my lab assistant, Ruth Baxter. We're taking her to Earth in the hope that we can reverse her condition. Our facilities on Mogar were too primitive.
What happened? How did she get in that state?
The experimental nature of our work entails some calculated risks.
Calculated risks? Are you telling me that sad travesty is a statistical possibility?
The word should be criminal.

Very well, perhaps I should have said unforeseen. During a particularly delicate cross-fertilisation, a speck of pollen penetrated a minute scratch on my assistant's thumb. She should never have left the wound uncovered.
There he is! Halt, or I'll fire.
Oh, Doctor, you do have the knack of landing yourself in hot water.
Satiable curtiosity, like the Elephant's Child.
Never mind the Just So stories. That guard looks trigger happy to me.
Simply doing his duty, miss. The regulations are quite specific. Anyone setting off a false alarm on an intergalactic liner is to be arrested forthwith.
No need to quote the book. I can explain.
Not to me, to the Commodore. He's expecting you. Take him.
No, that's all right. I know the way.
Doctor?
Hmm?
That way.
Yes, I know. It's that way.
Stop the Matrix. I fail to comprehend this evidence. The Doctor is on trial for his life, yet in his defence he presents us with a situation in which he is deliberately flouting accepted authority.
Much of your evidence does seem to contradict your stated aim, Doctor. Are you saying the Matrix is again being falsified?
No. And if the Valeyard would exercise the same restraint as I showed during his presentation of his case against me
Ha!
And could suppress his bloodlust
Doctor! This court is dedicated to giving you a fair trial. Do not abuse its indulgence.
I apologise.
The Matrix, Doctor. I suggest we return to the Hyperion Three.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The space liner is making another course correction.

Dialogue.Line: Bring us in closer. Reduce the margin by a factor of point naught one to naught two.
Very narrow margin of safety, Commodore.
Not to a ship of the Hyperion class.
Still risky, though. Quirky phenomena, black holes. They can gulp with unpredictable turbulence.
When I want your advice, I'll ask for it. (to guard) I'll handle this. Get back on duty.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The guard leaves.

Dialogue.Line: What I do want to hear from you is a reason why I shouldn't throw you in the brig. Fire alarms are not playthings for irresponsible buffoons.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Rudge and Mel are putting the smoke masks back at the fire point when Janet comes running.

Dialogue.Line: Mister Rudge! Mister Rudge.
What is it, Janet?
Mister Kimber has disappeared. He didn't report to the fire assembly point and he's not in his cabin.
He hasn't touched the drink I brought him.
Well, maybe he just wandered off, absent minded.
Without his jacket or his watch?
Now, when did you last see him?
I didn't. See him, that is. He was in the shower. I spoke to him through the door.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Rudge looks inside the bathroom.

Dialogue.Line: Where can he have got to? With all these killings
That'll do. Pull yourself together. Going to pieces won't help. We'll search the passenger quarters before we start assuming the worst.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Mel, who has been listening outside, waits until Rudge and Janet have gone down the corridor, then slips inside the cabin. She finds a large leaf in the grating under the sink, and runs out with it. Meanwhile, in the service ducts, several large plant beings are piling up bodies. They look like what Ruth is turning into.

Dialogue.Line: A grim picture.
I've no reason to lie, Commodore.
I'm not questioning your honesty, simply your methods. However, I'm left with little alternative but to begin to cooperate.
Begin? I take it you mean begin overtly to cooperate. You've been using me, Commodore. I would never have been allowed to run free if you hadn't condoned it.
Fair comment.
Frankly, I think you should notify the authorities about the death of the investigator Hallett, and insist on being given full details of his mission.
You underestimate me to that extent, do you?
Sorry. They refused.
Top secret. By the time they've gone through channels, we'll probably have docked.
Well, that can't happen.
No one will be allowed to disembark. The murderer won't escape.
Murderer? Yes. You'll let me know as soon as you get a reply?
Certainly, Doctor. I'll match you for candour.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Janet puts down the reception desk telephone as Rudge enters.

Dialogue.Line: Did you find him?
Not a sign. And you?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Janet shakes her head.

Dialogue.Line: I left a report we've lost another passenger. That'll improve the Commodore's temper, I'll guarantee.
Mister Rudge.
Er, later.
Wait. Come here. We want to know what is happening.
Yes, where was the fire?
It was a false alarm. There is nothing to worry about. You must excuse me. I have urgent things to do.
Sit down, Rudge.
There is only one thing you have got to do.
That is to tell us exactly what is going on.
And I suggest you do so right now.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: In a corridor, the guard investigates a rattling grill. One Vervoid attacks him from the front, another comes out of the grill and sticks a thorn in his neck. He falls with his activated communicator in his hand.

Dialogue.Line: Yes? What is it?
State your position.
Help me with this.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The two Vervoids carry the guard into the service ducts.

Dialogue.Line: Who the blazes was that? Trace that call.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Doland goes into the small lab at the back to find Bruchner destroying computer printouts.

Dialogue.Line: Have you gone out of your mind?
I have been, but not any more. I've regained my sanity.
It's not only your own work you're destroying. Other people have contributed. You've no right to do this!
You long ago lost sight of the difference between right and wrong.
Why? Because of some unexplained incidents?
On my way down here, I heard of another unexplained incident. That harmless old man is missing. How many more, Doland, before you and Lasky accept responsibility?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Bruchner continues to shred paper so Doland locks him in the little room.
The professor is on the static bicycle.

Dialogue.Line: I've no time for a horticultural discussion now, young woman. You and your erratic friend have already disrupted my routine.
I only asked you if you'd tell what this leaf is.
After my workout, and that's final.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Doland enters.

Dialogue.Line: I need to speak with you privately, Professor.
Really! Not now, Doland!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Mel moves away.

Dialogue.Line: I know how much you object to your work schedule being interrupted, but this is absolutely vital.
Well?
You must speak with Bruchner, calm him down.
Can't you?
Look, he won't listen to me.
Where is he?
In the Hydroponic Centre.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Lasky throws her towel at Doland and leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Mister Doland.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Mel opens the laundry box and he puts the towel in.

Dialogue.Line: Let's pick up where we left off while you're in the mood for explanations.
Did I give you that impression?
What are those pods in the Hydroponic Centre?
The results of another experiment.
I could have made an educated guess at that. What was in them?
Giant fruit. And anticipating your next question, we left the fruit on Mogar. We're merely taking the shucks as an example to fellow agronomists in earthbound laboratories. Now, if you'll excuse me.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Doland leaves. Mel hears heavy breathing coming from the air vent near the ceiling. She climbs the wall bars to listen, then goes back down and gets one of the aerobics headsets and puts its microphone through the vent before running into the control booth.

Dialogue.Line: Think, think.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: She starts adjusting controls.

Dialogue.Line: Amplifier.
We must not make animal-kind aware of our existence. They still outnumber us. If we are to kill them all, we must hunt them down secretly.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A hand in a white glove puts an anaesthetic gas mask over Mel's face. She screams.
The Doctor enters. It is deserted.

Dialogue.Line: Is there anybody there, said the traveller. Perhaps she's in the gym.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Mel is in laundry basket number 126. Someone puts a towel over her and shuts the lid, then a worker enters and exchanges it for a new one. The Doctor enters by another door.

Dialogue.Line: Ah, allow me. Wish I could get rid of my waste as easily, eh?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He pats his waistline. The worker leaves silently. The Doctor goes into the control booth and sees the Record light flashing on the console. He stops it, rewinds the tape and plays.

Dialogue.Line: We must not make animal-kind aware of our existence.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The worker takes the laundry basket to the waste disposal, where others are being emptied into the pulveriser.

Dialogue.Line: We must hunt them down secretly. (Mel screaming.)
Ah, allow me. Wish I could get rid of my waste as easily, eh?
The waste bins, where do they go?
Waste bins?
Quickly, woman. Where are they taken?
Well, the pulveriser, but why
The pulveriser!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor runs through the corridors. Mel's bin is next in line for the machine.

Dialogue.Line: Stop!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Just in time. The Doctor removes the lid and then the towel to reveal Mel. She begins to wake.

Dialogue.Line: Don't throw the towel in, Mel.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The space liner is approaching the area of the black hole.

Dialogue.Line: Why in Hades haven't you reported before now? As a security officer, you're an unmitigated disaster.
That's hardly fair, sir.
We've had a passenger murdered. According to you, another one's disappeared. Three crew members are missing, unaccounted for, and you haven't a clue as to why they've gone or where they are.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The guard is added to the pile of bodies.

Dialogue.Line: We are doing splendidly. VERVOID 2: Congratulations must be delayed until that is full.
We shall not have long to wait.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor runs into the control booth, followed by Mel.

Dialogue.Line: Doh! It's gone.
What has?
The tape. The proof we need to force Lasky's hand.
It's a waste of time. Our killer's obviously removed it.
Just as he tried to remove you.
He? Why not she?
Lasky?
Or the stewardess, Janet.
Janet? No.
It wouldn't have taken a man's strength to lift my weight. A woman could have dumped me in the waste bin.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They climb the wall bars to where the headset is still stuck in the grill.

Dialogue.Line: What are they, and how do they link with these murders?
Whatever they are, they're not human. And we're all to be destroyed, remember?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They jump down again.

Dialogue.Line: Still got that bit of leaf?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor compares her specimen to his.

Dialogue.Line: Where are you off to?
Hydroponic Centre. There has to be a connection.
And what about me?
Follow your lead. See if Janet has got the tape. But Mel, be careful, hmm?
You too, Doctor.
Can I tempt you with a coffee, sir?
No, thank you.
How about you, sir?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The other Mogarian knocks the tray out of Janet's hands, spilling the coffee down her uniform.

Dialogue.Line: Sorry.
Not to worry. It's easily changed.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: While Mel searches Janet's wardrobe, a shadow falls across the door outside. Then we switch to a view of the Doctor holding an axe amid wrecked computer equipment.

Dialogue.Line: I didn't do that!
Stop the Matrix.
Are we to be subjected to more chicanery, Sagacity?
It wasn't me in there.
Ridiculous. We all saw you. You're hardly mistakable in that outfit.
I didn't smash the equipment!
Are you saying the communications equipment was not sabotaged?
No, no, it had to be to prevent the Commodore getting information from Earth, but I didn't do it.
Then who did?
The murderer.
The murderer? I think, Inquisitor, the Doctor is telling us more than he realises.
The prosecutor delights in scoring cheap victories, my lady. I swear to you, when I viewed that section earlier, I was nowhere near the Communications room.
So once again the defendant is accusing the Matrix of being wrong.
Are you, Doctor?
Yes! Yes, I am.
If you are questioning its veracity, is there any point in continuing with the Matrix?
But what else have I got? Without evidence to prove my innocence, I'm condemned.
And with it you are also condemned, it seems, Doctor. Shall we continue?
Doctor? Shall we continue? You had, as before, sent your companion into danger.

Dialogue.Character: (In Janet's cabin, Mel hears the doorknob turning, and hides in the shower. It is a Vervoid. Meanwhile, the sabotage has been discovered.} TRAVERS
Dialogue.Line: Let's hope we don't need to call for outside help. There's no way we can repair this. We're completely isolated.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Lasky tips burnt paper from the waste bin onto the bench.

Dialogue.Line: Sheer vandalism, and utterly useless.
Is that how you see it, Professor?
How else?
Because I put an end to this obscene experiment?
I should think that when man first discovered fire there were those who were equally appalled and wanted it suppressed.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Vervoids are listening through a grating.

Dialogue.Line: If they'd prevailed, the human race would still be cowering in caves.
To use your own phrase, that's all academic now.
If you were rational, you'd realise how pointless this is. We can't unlearn knowledge. You're no illiterate. How often does a great advance produce this reaction. Think of Galileo.
Galileo? Oh, is that it? You see the name Lasky inscribed in the history books.
Rubbish. This has been a team effort.
